nodes.bodyText: Rather than piping to /dev/null, it is usually better to use -q so that error messages are shown.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -162,7 +173,7 @@ do
 
     if [ "${OWNER}" = "${GITHUB_USER}" ]; then
         ORIGIN=$(echo "${REPOHASH}" | awk '{print $3}')
-        git remote add unannotated "${ORIGIN}"
+        git remote add unannotated "${ORIGIN}" &> /dev/null

nodes.bodyText:
My intention was actually to suppress error messages, which I found distracting and unhelpful.
In particular, running git remote add twice on the same repository always causes an error, but I don't know of an easy way to check if the remote already exists. Since the script re-uses a repository if its already present (to avoid downloading the repo again unnecessarily), running the script twice deterministically produces failures from this line.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -162,7 +173,7 @@ do
 
     if [ "${OWNER}" = "${GITHUB_USER}" ]; then
         ORIGIN=$(echo "${REPOHASH}" | awk '{print $3}')
-        git remote add unannotated "${ORIGIN}"
+        git remote add unannotated "${ORIGIN}" &> /dev/null

nodes.bodyText: Thanks for the explanation.  Could you put a note in the file to explain that this usage is acceptable (even though in general one should not use it)?
